Reviews.Content: I stayed at Regal Riverside with my family last year and had never been so happy to leave a hotel. The corridors smelt damp and musty, and the room furnishings were old. Furthermore, our kettle was so old that flecks of metallic paint were coming off the inside of it so we were drinking water contaminated with metal for 2 days, before we noticed the problem. We then reported this to the staff who were extremely unhelpful and did not offer any apologies or discounts or refunds. They simply changed the kettle and, although the night duty manager promised to talk to us personally about it, he/she never turned up even though we waited 2 hours for him/her. The only good things about this hotel were the king sized bed and the convenient location in New Territories (where we were visiting friends). However, if it's your first time in Hong Kong, this hotel is not centrally located at all and I'd recommend that you try one of the better hotels on Hong Kong island.

Reviews.Title: “A nice hotel with reasonable price”
Reviews.Author: Dodo88
Reviews.Content: It is a nice 4-star hotel with good price. The location is not very good and the hotel is a bit old. But the room is really big and comfortable, with large king size bed and bath tub. The service is also excellent. They upgraded us to deluxe room because we booked by Amex. There was not much view, as we expected, but the comfortable large bed and clean beddings were really a pleasant surprise.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the room, hated the renovation”
Reviews.Author: landsurveyor
Reviews.Content: I was there with my wife and 18 mth infant on holiday and to visit relatives nearby. The room we got was fantastic. It was huge by HK standards, with tub and king sized bed. Foodwise, it is a 2 min walk to some diners and a mini market. Plenty of buses and cabs. Lovely river across the road for nighttime walkabouts. However, they were doing some renovations that was very noisy during daytime. Luckily I was out most of the day. Cost was about HK$700 per night.

Reviews.Title: “no sleep”
Reviews.Author: TILA_8
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 10 days in this hotel. I was totally dissatisfied with it because of the building work that was going on, I did not get much sleep because of hammering and drilling. They did agree to change rooms, but it was not much better. I was not aware of the building works when I booked and If I knew there would be building works I would have definitely not stayed there! The only compensation we got was a bowl of fruits that had seen better days! The atitude of the front desk staff was very poor. Tim, UK

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Inspection”
Reviews.Author: meowmel
Reviews.Content: Location Shatin, Close to the Shatin Racecourse (Official Racecourse for the Olympic Equestrian Games) 10 min to stadium where Rugby 7’s are held and horseracing 20min to Kowloon by MTR (station within walking distance) HKD16 approx to Central Kowloon in a taxi Rooms Spacious basic furnishings, slightly dated décor but clean and tidy, shower over bath Superior and Premium: Difference between this and a superior is the level (Premium starts from the 10th floor) Deluxe: We saw the newly renovated ones (make sure you ask for this as only half the rooms have currently been done) Double/Double bedding , all River facing, Can get adjourning rooms in this grade only Triple and Quad Rooms: We saw a Quad room, it was huge would defiantly recommend for a family or group of friends travelling as all fixed bedding Family rooms: One double bed and one single Suite: Separate bedroom with king bed, ensuite plus other bathroom, lounge (with foldout sofa) No Disabled rooms available **Renovations till March 2009, done 9am-5pm, one floor buffer between guests and renovations** Comments/Recommendations This was a really nice property with almost a resort atmosphere. The lobby was really light with funky, modern furnishings. Wireless internet is available though-out the whole building, and they have 5 restaurants located at the property (2 Chinese, 1 Japanese, 1 Italian, and 1 seafood) and 2 bars.

Reviews.Title: “If you want to sleep past 8.30 am DO NOT GO HERE UNTIL END OF JAN 2009”
Reviews.Author: Jacquesmeister
Reviews.Content: This hotel is nice inside and pretty much quite posh to look at. If you'relooking for something near to the centre of Hong Kong then don't go here as you are really just in the middle of the suburb Shatin. The main disappointment was the noise we had to put up with. We were using this hotel as a stopover between UK and NZ and we couldn't sleep in any longer than 8.30am as there was ridiculously loud building work going on on top of the roof of the hotel. It was banging of hammers, pneumatic drills and shouting. The manager of the hotel said he had placed us as far away from the noise as possible, but it seemed that the hammers were banging directly above us. We were informed 3 days before our arrival to this hotel that the building work was going on so we had no time to change or get a refund. Nothing was offered to us in any form of compensation and I was thoroughly disappointed and VERY tired! NB the pool is also going to be closed until January 2009.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel, make sure that the location is suitable for you”
Reviews.Author: SuppersReady
Reviews.Content: This was the second time we've stayed at the Riverside as it's handy for visiting my wife's family in the New Territories. The hotel itself was pretty good and exceptional value compared to hotels in Kowloon. The room was immaculate and unexpectedly large. It's easy to get to from the airport (the A41 bus stops right outside) despite being out of the main tourist areas. However, if you are thinking about staying here there are two things that you need to consider. First, if you have a basic room only package then paying for other things at the hotel can work out quite expensive. The restaurants appeared comparatively pricy (especially for breakfast) and, as has been writen previously, they will charge you 70HKD for an hour's internet use in the hotel business centre. Secondly, the location. It's a 15 minute walk to the KCR station and the interconnected shopping plazas at Sha Tin. Although it's not an unpleasant walk, it does add significantly to the time taken to travel around. If you don't want to eat in the hotel there are many restaurants in the Sha Tin shopping malls and in the local area close by. However, unlike previous posters, I didn't see many English menus in the smaller, and better value, restaurants (these places are, quite rightly, geared to local customers so there is no reason why they should have them) and would have missed out on a lot of delicious food if not for the fact that my wife is Hong Kong Chinese. If time is tight in Hong Kong and you need to be closer to the main attractions then the Riverside mightn't be the best bet for you. However, if you enjoy being in an area that is probably more representative of typical Hong Kong life than Kowloon, then you could do much worse.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent breakfast”
Reviews.Author: mightymonkey
Reviews.Content: We just spent two weeks at the Regal Riverside Hotel in Sha Tin, and were really impressed with it. First of all, I would recommend that you shop around for the best price. I found the best price on asiarooms, and that was about 45GBPounds per night for a twin, including buffet breakfast for two. The shuttle bus from the airport costs 110 HKDollars one way per person, and the bus leaves about once every 75 mins. If you miss a bus and have to wait around, that doesn't matter, because there are plenty of shops and restaurants at the airport, and then you walk over to the Regal Airport Hotel (2 mins) to wait for the bus in air-conditioned comfort there! Once on the bus, it takes about 40 mins to get to the hotel. I wondered about getting public transport to the hotel, but having taken the shuttle bus, I would recommend that others do the same. It's hassle-free and the airport express train plus a bus/taxi/KCR, would cost more or less the same, if not a bit more. So, for convenience and time, the bus would be the best bet. I emailed the hotel two days beforehand, and my name was put on a list at the Regal Hotels airport travel desk - very easy to find as soon as you come through the arrivals gate. Coming back to the airport was the same - we booked it a day before, and it was a stress-free journey from hotel to airport. Incidentally, the shuttle bus also stops at Disneyland between the airport and the hotel, so this would also be convenient, if you chose to go there. The hotel itself is fine. The room was cleaned everyday; notices were often put under the door to notify you of fire alarms, telephone checks, extreme weather warnings (in our case, a Level 8 Typhoon!) etc; we had a variety of TV channels, including about 4 English ones and all the usual that you would expect from a hotel. We didn't have a room overlooking the river, but that didn't bother us, because the view was pretty nice anyway, especially at night when all the lights appeared. During the day, there was a lot of cloud, but we could see a high school and green hills. There was a swimming pool, but we didn't use it although we had our swimming gear with us! It's surrounded by rooms, and a restaurant, so those less self-conscious might be happy to use it - I wasn't! We did have a massage, which was excellent, and just what we needed. An hour cost about 300HKD. The breakfast was excellent. It catered to all tastes. There was (prepare yourself) -fried rice, baked beans, ham, sausages, hash browns, spring rolls, samosas, miso soup, fresh made-to-order omelettes, toast, patisserie goods - mini croissants etc, juice, cereal, tea, coffee, broth/congee and extras, dim sum, fruit, salads.. and maybe more that I can't remember! I was highly impressed, as I wasn't sure what to expect beforehand. It's worth paying the extra for the breakfast, unless you are willing to wait until you get to New Town Plaza everyday and look for a cafe or bakery to get something. The New Town Plaza plays a major role in any stay at this hotel. It's just across the river, so a 10-15 min walk, or a 2 min bus ride. Jump on any bus which says 'Sha Tin Town Centre' or 'Sha Tin KCR Station'. Depending on which bus you hop on, it can cost 2.50-4 HKD. The smaller buses are cheaper, I paid 4 once on a fully air-conditioned double decker bus. If you take 299 or 284, it costs 3.10 - either pay by swiping an Octopus (travel) Card or with the exact change, which you throw into the metal money box. You can buy an Octopus card at the KCR station - the staff speak good English. We walked a few times - at night it was warm and breezy, so it was OK, but to be honest, we were so wiped out by the heat and humidity, we mostly took the bus. Mostly a bus would come along every minute or so. We barely had to wait at all. To get back to the hotel from the bus station on the ground level of NTP, take 284 or 299 and it's the second stop. I think 284 goes more often. The Plaza stays open until very late; getting in at 9pm or so, all the shops are still open and the restaurants are full - the place is still buzzing with people. The KCR station is very easy to find in the Plaza. In terms of food, if you can speak a bit of Chinese (I never heard them speak English, and the menus were all in Chinese with no pictures), there is an excellent and cheap restaurant about 20m away behind the hotel. A bowl of noodles costs 18 HKD after 2.30pm! Otherwise, go over to the NTP - plenty of restaurants with English menus. I wouldn't go for the hotel restaurants myself. Apart from the breakfast, I thought they were overpriced. For those on a real budget, there is a 7-11 just behind the hotel as well! We also went to Ocean Park, which was a huge tourist trap. There were soooooo many people there, and there were huge queues for everything - even just to get drinks, it totally put us off going to Disneyland. In Sha Tin we went to the Heritage Museum, which was a bit disappointing. It's a lovely building, but we spent less than an hour there. Maybe we weren't in the mood. The museum shop was really random: it felt and looked just like a UK gift shop, with nothing in it that was related to the museum itself. However, the tea rooms have a set menu everyday for 40 HKD, and we both agreed that it was probably the cleanest place we had eaten all fortnight! Despite my happiness with the hotel and its location, I wouldn't recommend it to people who are mainly going to be visiting Hong Kong Island, Kowloon etc. For us to get to Central it took about an hour (maybe a bit less) and so if you are planning on going to Lantau Island, with the KCR, ferry etc, there and back takes quite a chunk out of the day. Personally, I know that if I return to HKG I will stay at this hotel again, because it is well placed for going both north and south, it was clean,the breakfast was good and it was a decent price.

Reviews.Title: “Shatin hotel”
Reviews.Author: sndaily
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a 4 night stay in Hong Kong with our kids. We only booked a week before, so had a narrower choice of hotels - would have stayed at the Salisbury YMCA hotel. Decided to stay out in Shatin as we were planning a Sunday at the horse races anyway (only to find out at the track that kids under 18 are not allowed). The Royal Park was booked so we went with the Regal Riverside. The hotel was fine - a little older, but large connecting rooms overlooking the river with nice comfortable beds - king in one room and 2 twins next door. The hotel staff had upgraded us to the Regal floor and threw in a free bus tour of Hong Kong which we didn't think we'd use at first but came in very handy on a rainy Monday! The location wasn't perfect, but it was only a 5 minute walk across the river to the KCR station and an easy 15 - 20 minute journey to Tsim Sha Tsui. The A41 airport bus goes right to the hotel which was another plus. The hotel gave us a free shuttle back to the airport. Going in and out of the city became a little tiresome but for the price I couldn't find a similar quality hotel closer in (we paid HK$ 850 per room per night.
